notes: Filing deadline: original contractor 6 months; others 4 months after last furnishing (Ala. Code §35-11-215). Non-original contractors must give written notice of lien claim to owner BEFORE filing statement (Ala. Code §35-11-218). Verified statement is filed in probate office (judge of probate) and must be sworn (Ala. Code §35-11-213). Enforcement suit due within 6 months after maturity of the debt (Ala. Code §35-11-221) — trigger here uses contract_date as proxy; laborer 30-day filing category not modeled in this sheet.

Lien filing deadline: 120 days after claimant completes contract or ceases furnishing (AS 34.35.068(a)). If owner records Notice of Completion (AS 34.35.071), some claimants must record a claim of lien OR a Notice of Right to Lien within 15 days (AS 34.35.068(b)(1)); recording a Notice of Right to Lien can preserve the 120-day lien deadline in certain cases (AS 34.35.068(b)(2); AS 34.35.064). Enforcement: lien expires unless action commenced within 6 months of recording or an extension notice is recorded within the original 6 months (AS 34.35.080).

penalty_details: A.R.S. §33-420: min $5,000 or treble actual damages + attorney fees; class 1 misdemeanor possible
notes: Preliminary 20-day notice prerequisite (except wage laborers): A.R.S. §33-992.01(B); due within 20 days of first furnishing: §33-992.01(C). Lien deadline: 120 days after completion, or 60 days after Notice of Completion recorded: A.R.S. §33-993(A). Claim of lien made under oath and recorded with county recorder; serve copy on owner within reasonable time: A.R.S. §33-993(A). Foreclosure suit within 6 months of recording + lis pendens: A.R.S. §33-998. Owner-occupied dwelling: lien only with direct written contract with owner-occupant: A.R.S. §33-1002(B).

NOI: 10-day notice to owner before filing lien (Ark. Code Ann. §18-44-114(a)). Lien filing deadline: within 120 days after work/materials furnished; file with clerk of the circuit court and include affidavit of notice/proof (Ark. Code Ann. §18-44-117(a)(1), (a)(3)). Commercial projects: subs/service providers/material suppliers/laborers must send 75-day notice to owner and contractor (Ark. Code Ann. §18-44-115(b)(4)-(5)). Residential (<=4 units): no lien unless owner received the statutory pre-construction notice; residential contractor must provide it before commencement (Ark. Code Ann. §18-44-115(a)(1), (a)(3), (a)(5)(C)). Enforcement: action must be commenced within 15 months after filing lien and a lis pendens filed (Ark. Code Ann. §18-44-119(a)-(b)).

penalty_details: Cal. Civ. Code §8422: willfully exaggerated claim can forfeit lien; claimant liable for damages and attorney fees
notes: Prelim (20-day) notice due within 20 days of first furnishing (Cal. Civ. Code §8204); late notice only preserves rights for work within 20 days before service. Direct contractors are generally exempt from prelim unless serving a construction lender (see Civ. Code §8200). Lien recording deadline: Direct contractor—before earlier of 90 days after completion or 60 days after Notice of Completion/Cessation recorded (§8412). Other claimants—before earlier of 90 days after completion or 30 days after Notice recorded (§8414). Notice of Completion must be recorded on/within 15 days after completion (§8182) to be valid. After recording lien, serve copy of the claim on the owner (Civ. Code §8416). Enforcement: file foreclosure action within 90 days after recordation (§8460), unless an extension of credit is recorded.

penalty_details: C.R.S. §38-35-204: expedited procedure for spurious liens; prevailing party awarded costs incl. reasonable attorney fees
notes: NOI required: serve Notice of Intent to File Lien Statement on owner and principal contractor at least 10 days before filing; serve by personal service or registered/certified mail and record affidavit with lien (C.R.S. §38-22-109(3)). Lien filing deadline: most claimants must record lien statement within 4 months after last labor/materials furnished (C.R.S. §38-22-109(5)); labor-only (day/piece, no materials) has different deadline (C.R.S. §38-22-109(4)) not modeled here. Enforcement: lien holds property no longer than 6 months after last work/materials or completion unless foreclosure action commenced AND notice of action recorded (C.R.S. §38-22-110). Spurious lien remedy includes attorney fees to prevailing party (C.R.S. §38-35-204).

Lien filing: certificate must be lodged/recorded with the town clerk within 90 days after ceasing to furnish labor/materials (Conn. Gen. Stat. §49-34). Serve a true and attested copy of the recorded certificate on the owner not later than 30 days after lodging (Conn. Gen. Stat. §49-34). Non-original contractors generally must give written notice to owner and original contractor after commencing and not later than 90 days after ceasing (Conn. Gen. Stat. §49-35(a)); service is by indifferent person/state marshal or by registered/certified mail if out of town. Original contractor affidavit (business name/address + property description) is lodged with town clerk not later than 15 days after commencing (Conn. Gen. Stat. §49-35(a)). Enforcement: lien not in force longer than 1 year after perfected unless foreclosure commenced and lis pendens recorded within that period (Conn. Gen. Stat. §49-39).

Direct contractor filing deadline: statement of claim within 180 days after completion of structure; statute also deems timely if filed within 180 days of several alternative events (e.g., final invoice, certificate of occupancy, 90% payment) (25 Del. C. §2711(a)). All other claimants: statement of claim within 120 days from completion of labor/last delivery of materials; also deemed timely within 120 days of (i) when final payment (incl. retainage) is due to claimant or (ii) when final payment is made to the direct contractor (25 Del. C. §2711(b)). Statement of claim/complaint is filed with the Prothonotary of the Superior Court (25 Del. C. §2712(a)) and must be supported by claimant affidavit (25 Del. C. §2712(c)). Proceeding to recover is by writ of scire facias (25 Del. C. §2714).

penalty_details: Fla. Stat. §713.31: fraudulent lien (willful exaggeration etc.) is complete defense; lien unenforceable; damages incl. attorney fees and punitive damages may apply
notes: Prelim (Notice to Owner) required for parties not in privity with owner; must be served before commencing or not later than 45 days after commencing to furnish (Fla. Stat. §713.06(2)(a)). Lien recording deadline: claim of lien recorded no later than 90 days after final furnishing by the lienor (Fla. Stat. §713.08). Serve claim of lien on owner before recording or within 15 days after recording (Fla. Stat. §713.08(4)(c) referencing §713.18). Enforcement: lien expires 1 year after recording unless action commenced (and lis pendens as applicable) (Fla. Stat. §713.22(1)). Tenant improvements generally lien only tenant’s interest unless owner authorizes/implies agency; treat as owner_consent_required in this sheet.

Lien filing deadline: file claim of lien within 90 days after completion of work or last furnishing of labor/materials (O.C.G.A. §44-14-361.1(a)(2)). If a Notice of Commencement is filed, remote claimants must send a Notice to Contractor within 30 days (generally the later of 30 days after NOC filing or 30 days after first furnishing) by registered/certified mail or statutory overnight delivery to owner and contractor (O.C.G.A. §44-14-361.5(c)). Post-lien notice: within 2 business days after filing, send copy of claim of lien to owner (and also to contractor if NOC filed) by registered/certified mail or statutory overnight delivery (O.C.G.A. §44-14-361.1(a)). Enforcement: commence lien action within 365 days after lien filing AND file a Notice of Commencement of Lien Action within 30 days after commencing the action (O.C.G.A. §44-14-361.1(a)(3)).

Hawaii lien is initiated by filing an Application for a Lien + Notice of Lien in circuit court; copies must be served like a summons on owner, contracting party, general contractor, and persons with an interest (HRS §507-43(a)). Filing deadline: Application + Notice must be filed not later than 45 days after the statutory 'date of completion' (HRS §507-43(b)). 'Date of completion' is tied to publication of notice of completion/abandonment + affidavit filed with circuit court clerk; if no valid notice within 1 year after actual completion/abandonment, completion is deemed 1 year after actual completion/abandonment (HRS §507-43(f),(g)). Lien attaches only after court finds probable cause and enters an Order Directing Lien to Attach; lien expires 3 months after entry of that order unless proceedings are commenced (HRS §507-43(e)). Land Court property: file certified copy of the Order Directing Lien to Attach with assistant registrar within 7 days (HRS §507-43(b)).

Lien recording deadline: claim must be recorded within 90 days after completion of labor/services or furnishing of materials (Idaho Code §45-507(2)). Serve a true and correct copy of the recorded claim on the owner or reputed owner by personal service or certified mail no later than 5 business days after filing (Idaho Code §45-507(5)). Enforcement: lien binds property no longer than 6 months after filing unless proceedings commenced within that time; can be extended if payment/credit with expiration date is endorsed and recorded (Idaho Code §45-510(1)). Residential disclosure: for residential real property contracts >$2,000, general contractor must provide disclosure prior to entering contract (Idaho Code §45-525(2)).

Subcontractor/supplier 90-day notice: must provide written notice of claim to owner (or agent/architect/superintendent) and to lending agency (if known) within 90 days; service by registered/certified mail RRR, nationally recognized delivery company with tracking, or personal service (770 ILCS 60/24(a); Public Act 103-0827 expands service options). Contractor claim for lien: to have priority against creditors/incumbrancers/purchasers, contractor must file claim for lien OR bring action within 4 months after completion (770 ILCS 60/7(a)). As to the owner, contractor claim for lien may be filed within 2 years after completion of the contract/extra work (770 ILCS 60/7(a)). Enforcement suit must be commenced within 2 years after completion of the contract/extra work/materials (770 ILCS 60/9). Owner-occupied single-family residence: contractor must give owner written notice within 10 days after recording lien; otherwise lien can be extinguished to extent of damages (770 ILCS 60/7(d)).

Owner-occupied 1-2 family: if not contracting directly with owner, claimant must give written notice of first delivery/work + lien rights within 30 days (alter/repair) (IC 32-28-3-1(h)) or within 60 days AND file a copy with recorder within 60 days for original construction sold/furnished on credit (IC 32-28-3-1(i)). Lien recording deadline: file 'statement and notice of intention to hold a lien' in county recorder within 60 days for Class 2 (residential) or within 90 days otherwise (IC 32-28-3-3). Enforcement: foreclosure action must be commenced not later than 1 year after the lien was recorded (IC 32-28-3-6).

Perfection: mechanic’s lien is perfected by posting a verified statement of account to the Mechanics’ Notice and Lien Registry (MNLR) (Iowa Code §572.8). Timing: lien statement may be posted within 2 years and 90 days after last furnishing (Iowa Code §572.9), but if posted after 90 days, additional service is required and the lien’s enforceable extent can be limited (Iowa Code §§572.10–.11). Residential construction: GC must give owner notice (Iowa Code §572.13) and must post a Notice of Commencement to MNLR within 10 days after commencement or loses lien rights (Iowa Code §572.13A). Residential subcontractor: must post MNLR preliminary notice; it must be posted before the balance due is paid to the GC/owner-builder or the subcontractor has no lien remedy (Iowa Code §572.13B). Commercial: a person furnishing labor/materials to a subcontractor must give a one-time written notice to the GC/owner-builder within 30 days of first furnishing (Iowa Code §572.33). Enforcement: action to enforce must be brought within 2 years from expiration of 90 days after last furnishing (Iowa Code §572.27); owner demand can accelerate to 30 days (Iowa Code §572.28). Prelim (commercial/residential subs/suppliers): post MNLR preliminary notice within 30 days of first furnishing for full protection.

Prime/original contractor lien statement: file within 4 months after last furnishing labor/materials; may extend to 5 months on non-residential only by filing a notice of extension within the original 4 months (K.S.A. §60-1102(a),(c)). Subcontractor/supplier lien statement: file within 3 months after last furnishing; may extend to 5 months on non-residential only by filing a notice of extension within the original 3 months (K.S.A. §60-1103(a)(1),(e)). Residential improvement (1–2 family): subs/suppliers must have mailed the statutory warning statement (or have owner-signed acknowledgment) to claim a lien (K.S.A. §60-1103a). New residential property: to preserve lien rights after deed passes to a good-faith purchaser for value, claimant must have filed a Notice of Intent to Perform prior to deed recordation (K.S.A. §60-1103b(b)); NOI-to-perform expires after 18 months unless lien filed (K.S.A. §60-1103b(f)). After filing, claimant must serve a copy of lien statement on owner/recorded equitable interest holder/party obligated to pay via personal service, restricted mail, or posting (K.S.A. §60-1103(c)). Foreclosure action deadline: within 1 year after filing lien statement (K.S.A. §60-1105(a)). Prelim for certain residential jobs: warning statement/notice of intent to perform must be served before lien filing; no fixed day-count deadline.

penalty_details: KRS §376.220(3): damages + reasonable court costs and attorney fees for filing in excess of amount actually due
notes: Pre-lien notice for non-direct claimants: notice of intent within 75 days (<$1,000) or 120 days (>$1,000) after last furnishing (KRS 376.010(4)); owner-occupied 1–2 family/ag/personal: notice within 75 days after last furnishing (KRS 376.010(5)) in lieu of (4). Tenant work: lessee not owner's agent unless owner designates in writing (KRS 376.010(1)(b)). Lien statement: file within 6 months after ceasing to labor/furnish; subscribed and sworn (KRS 376.080(1)). Mail copy to owner within 7 days of filing or lien dissolved (KRS 376.080(1)). Enforce within 12 months after filing (KRS 376.090(1)).

General preservation deadline: statement of claim/privilege within 60 days after (i) filing of notice of termination or (ii) substantial completion/abandonment if no termination filed (La. R.S. 9:4822(A)). If a timely notice of contract is filed (La. R.S. 9:4811), claimants under 9:4802 must file within 30 days after termination OR within 6 months after substantial completion/abandonment if no termination (9:4822(B)); general contractor then has 60 days after termination OR 7 months after substantial completion/abandonment if no termination (9:4822(C)). Residential (no timely notice of contract): certain claimants may extend to 70 days by giving owner a notice of nonpayment at least 10 days before filing (9:4822(D)) — mapped here as NOI=10 days (conditional). Enforcement: privilege extinguished if suit not filed within 1 year after filing statement (La. R.S. 9:4823(A)(2)); to keep effect against third persons, file notice of pendency within 1 year after statement filing (La. R.S. 9:4833(E)). Notice of contract must be filed before work begins (La. R.S. 9:4811).

Lien certificate must be recorded in the registry of deeds within 90 days after the lien claimant last performed labor or furnished materials (10 M.R.S. §3253). A copy of the lien certificate must be given to the owner (and certain others) within 30 days after recording (10 M.R.S. §3253). Enforcement: action to enforce lien must be commenced within 120 days after last labor/materials (10 M.R.S. §3255). Because enforcement is keyed to last furnishing (not recording date), this sheet sets enforcement_trigger=last_furnish_date.

Subcontractor notice: subcontractor is not entitled to a lien unless, within 120 days after doing the work or furnishing materials, it gives the owner written notice of intention to claim a lien (Md. Code, Real Prop. §9-104(a)(1)); for owner-occupied single-family residence, lien is barred if owner made full payment to contractor before receiving the notice (§9-104(a)(2)). Petition deadline: file proceedings (petition to establish mechanic’s lien) in the circuit court within 180 days after the work has been finished or materials furnished (Real Prop. §9-105(a)). Enforcement: right to enforce a lien established expires 1 year from the day the petition to establish lien was first filed (Real Prop. §9-109) — this sheet uses enforcement_trigger=lien_recorded_date as proxy for petition filing date.

penalty_details: M.G.L. c.254 §11: lien validity can be affected if claimant wilfully and knowingly claims more than due
statute_reference: M.G.L. c.254 §§ 4, 8, 11 (and §§2A–2B for substantial completion/termination notices)
notes: Notice of Contract (subs/suppliers) deadline: file/record not later than earliest of (i) 60 days after Notice of Substantial Completion (§2A), (ii) 90 days after Notice of Termination (§2B), or (iii) 90 days after last furnishing by GC or those claiming through GC (M.G.L. c.254 §4). Sub-sub / lower-tier without direct contract with original contractor: lien amount can be limited unless Notice of Identification is sent to the original contractor within 30 days of commencing performance by certified mail RRR (c.254 §4). Statement of Account deadline: file/record not later than earliest of (i) 90 days after Notice of Substantial Completion, (ii) 120 days after Notice of Termination, or (iii) 120 days after last furnishing (c.254 §8). Enforcement: civil action to enforce lien must be commenced within 90 days after filing the §8 statement (c.254 §11). Also, an attested copy of the complaint must be recorded in the registry of deeds within 30 days after commencement of the action (c.254 §5/§11 practice—see guidance); not represented in this sheet.

penalty_details: MCL 570.1118: willfully exaggerating lien amount can create liability for damages/attorney fees; lien may be forfeited to extent of excess
notes: Notice of Furnishing: subs/suppliers must provide within 20 days of first furnishing to preserve full lien amount (MCL 570.1109(1)); late notice limits lien to unpaid amounts owed after notice is received (MCL 570.1109(4)). Lien recording: record claim of lien within 90 days after last furnishing (MCL 570.1111(1)). Serve copy of recorded claim of lien on owner within 15 days after recording (MCL 570.1111(4)). Enforcement: foreclose within 1 year after recording (MCL 570.1117(1)). Excessive lien liability: damages/fees for willful exaggeration; court may reduce/forfeit excess (MCL 570.1118).

Direct contractor notice: must include statutory lien notice in written contract; if no written contract, deliver personally or by certified mail within 10 days after work is agreed upon (Minn. Stat. §514.011 subd. 1). Subcontractor/supplier notice: must be given personally or by certified mail within 45 days after first furnishing (Minn. Stat. §514.011 subd. 2), subject to statutory exceptions (e.g., certain >4-unit residential and certain >5,000 sq ft nonresidential improvements). Lien statement: lien ceases 120 days after last work/materials unless within that period the lien statement is filed and a copy served personally or by certified mail on the owner/agent or person who contracted (Minn. Stat. §514.08 subd. 1). Statement must be verified by oath and include first/last furnishing dates and acknowledgement of service and, if applicable, §514.011 notice (Minn. Stat. §514.08 subd. 2). Enforcement: must commence action (complaint/answer) within 1 year after the date of the last item stated in the recorded lien statement; lis pendens absence after that year is conclusive as to bona fide purchasers (Minn. Stat. §514.12 subd. 3).

Lien filing deadline: file 'claim of lien' in the office of the clerk of the chancery court (chancery clerk) within 90 days after last labor/materials (Miss. Code Ann. §85-7-131). Enforcement: suit to enforce must be commenced within 180 days after filing the lien (Miss. Code Ann. §85-7-141). Residential notice to owner requirements exist for claimants not in privity with owner and can impact lien rights; this sheet marks a 30-day prelim as a proxy, but Mississippi notice rules vary by residential/commercial and by claimant type (see §85-7-181 and related sections).

penalty_details: RSMo §429.014 lien fraud: class D felony if >$500, else class A misdemeanor; §429.012(3) class B misdemeanor if original contractor fails notice with intent to defraud
notes: Original contractor must give 'Notice to Owner' disclosure prior to receiving any payment (may be given at contract, delivery, commencement, or with first invoice); this is a condition precedent to original contractor lien rights (RSMo §429.012). Non-original contractors must give 10 days' notice before filing lien (RSMo §429.100). Lien statement deadline: file verified 'just and true account' with circuit clerk within 6 months after indebtedness accrued; equipment lessor has 60-day deadline and 15-business-day owner notice for commercial equipment liens (RSMo §§429.080, 429.010(2)). Enforcement: commence action within 6 months after filing lien and prosecute without unnecessary delay (RSMo §429.170). Owner-occupied residential (repair/remodel/addition, <=4 units): subs/suppliers must have owner-signed 'Consent of Owner' and attach it to lien filing; full payment to contractor is defense absent consent (RSMo §429.013). Residential sale 'notice of intended sale' / claimant 'notice of rights' (not less than 5 days before closing) can apply in certain sale situations; does not extend lien deadline (RSMo §429.016).

Prelim (Notice of Right to Claim Lien) required for claimants without direct contract with owner; generally due within 20 days of first furnishing (MCA 71-3-531). If notice is late, lien enforceable only for services/materials furnished within 45 days before notice is given (MCA 71-3-531). A copy of the notice must be filed with county clerk/recorder within 5 business days after giving it to the contracting owner (MCA 71-3-531(6)(a)). Lien filing deadline: file lien within 90 days after final furnishing OR within 90 days after owner files a Notice of Completion (MCA 71-3-535(1)). Lien must be served on each owner of record (personal service or certified mail RRR) and certification of service must accompany filing (MCA 71-3-534(2); 71-3-535(2)(b)). Enforcement: action must be commenced within 2 years from filing of lien (MCA 71-3-562).

Lien statement must be filed within 120 days after the claimant ceased furnishing labor or materials (Neb. Rev. Stat. §52-103). Serve copy of lien statement on the owner within 10 days after filing (Neb. Rev. Stat. §52-109). Enforcement: commence action to enforce within 2 years after filing the lien (Neb. Rev. Stat. §52-118).

penalty_details: NRS 108.226(4): knowingly false statement re lien recording is gross misdemeanor; fine $5,000-$10,000
notes: Prelim (Notice of Right to Lien): required for lien claimants other than laborers and those contracting directly with owner; deliver to owner by personal service or certified mail; subcontractor/supplier must also send a copy to prime contractor (info only) (NRS 108.245(1),(5)). If notice is served more than 31 days after first furnishing, lien covers only work/materials within 31 days before notice + thereafter (NRS 108.245(6)). Lien recording: record notice of lien within 90 days after latest of completion / last delivery / last work, or within 40 days after valid Notice of Completion recorded and served (NRS 108.226(1); 108.228). Residential/multifamily/single-family: must serve 15-day Notice of Intent to Lien on owner and reputed prime contractor before recording; extends recording deadline by 15 days (NRS 108.226(6)). Serve copy of recorded lien on owner within 30 days after recording (NRS 108.227). Enforcement: lien lasts 6 months after recording unless action commenced (NRS 108.233).

Subcontractor/supplier notice: for those contracting with a GC/sub, written notice to owner/person in charge is required to claim a lien before performing/furnishing (RSA 447:5); notice may also be given after, but lien is limited to amounts then due or thereafter due to the contractor/agent/sub (RSA 447:6). After giving notice, claimant must provide a written accounting as often as once in 30 days (RSA 447:8). Lien duration: lien continues for 120 days after services/materials are furnished (RSA 447:9). Perfection: lien is secured by court attachment of the property at any time while the lien continues (RSA 447:10); attachment is then recorded at the registry of deeds. Pre-lien notice has no strict statutory day-count deadline; notice triggers owner's duty to withhold and 30-day accountings may apply.

Non-residential: lien claim must be lodged for record within 90 days after last work/materials for which payment is claimed (N.J.S.A. 2A:44A-6(a)(2)). Residential construction contract: lien claim must be lodged not later than 10 days after receipt of arbitrator's determination and within 120 days after last work/materials (N.J.S.A. 2A:44A-21(b)(8); see also 2A:44A-6). Residential prerequisite: claimant must file a Notice of Unpaid Balance and Right to File Lien (NUB) within 60 days after last work/materials and demand arbitration; NUB is effective for 120 days on residential claims (N.J.S.A. 2A:44A-20; 2A:44A-21). Service: within 10 days after lodging for record, serve copy on owner and (if any) contractor/subcontractor against whom claim asserted (N.J.S.A. 2A:44A-7(a)). Enforcement: commence action in Superior Court within 1 year of last work/materials OR within 30 days after written demand (N.J.S.A. 2A:44A-14(a)).

penalty_details: Failure to send copy of filed claim within 15 days may preclude recovery of interest, attorney fees, or costs (NMSA 48-2-6(B)).
notes: Preliminary notice threshold: liens > $5,000 generally require written notice of right to claim lien within 60 days after initially furnishing, delivered to owner or original contractor (NMSA 48-2-2.1(B)); late notice limits lien to work/materials furnished on/after 30 days before notice (48-2-2.1(E)). Case annotations indicate original contractor and first-level subcontractors not required to give this notice; third-level and higher must (Wilgert Enters., Inc. v. Broadway Vista Partners). Lien filing deadline: original contractor within 120 days after completion of contract; all other persons within 90 days after completion of the building/improvement/repair (NMSA 48-2-6(A)). Post-filing notice: mail/email/certified RRR/hand deliver copy of filed claim to owner within 15 days; failure may preclude interest/fees/costs (NMSA 48-2-6(B)). Enforcement: lien not valid longer than 2 years after claim filed unless suit or binding arbitration commenced (NMSA 48-2-10).

penalty_details: NY Lien Law §§39 & 39-a: willful exaggeration can forfeit lien and create liability for damages incl. attorney fees
notes: Private improvement lien deadline: 4 months after last work/materials for single-family dwelling; 8 months for other private improvements (NY Lien Law §10). Serve copy on owner within 30 days after filing (NY Lien Law §11). Lien expires 1 year after filing unless foreclosure action commenced or extended (NY Lien Law §17). Willful exaggeration can forfeit lien and create damages/fee liability (NY Lien Law §§39, 39-a).

filing_location: Clerk of Superior Court (county where property is located)
penalty_details: Possible attorneys' fees for prevailing party in lien actions (G.S. 44A-35).
notes: Notice to Lien Agent generally required on projects with a designated lien agent; best practice to send within 15 days of first furnishing for full protection. Claim of Lien on Real Property must be filed and served within 120 days after last furnishing; enforcement action/lis pendens within 180 days of last furnishing.

penalty_details: N.D.C.C. §35-27-24.1: owner awarded full costs and reasonable attorney fees if owner successfully contests lien validity/accuracy
notes: Pre-lien notice: send owner certified-mail notice at least 10 days before recording the lien (N.D.C.C. §35-27-02). Record lien within 90 days after contribution is done; lien statement includes first/last contribution dates; absolute cap: not more than 3 years after first material is furnished (N.D.C.C. §35-27-13). Pre-suit enforcement notice: 10 days (personal) or 20 days (registered mail) before suit (N.D.C.C. §35-27-24). Owner demand can accelerate: suit + lis pendens within 30 days or lien forfeited; also suit+lis pendens must occur within 3 years after lien recording (N.D.C.C. §35-27-25). Tenant work: no lien unless owner has notice and fails to object (N.D.C.C. §35-27-07(3)).

Notice of Furnishing: for claimants without direct contract, when a Notice of Commencement is filed, serve Notice of Furnishing not later than 21 days after first furnishing; late notice limits lien to work/materials furnished within 21 days before service and thereafter (Ohio Rev. Code §1311.05). Lien filing (private): affidavit for mechanic’s lien generally within 75 days after last furnishing; for work on a one- or two-family dwelling, within 60 days after last furnishing (Ohio Rev. Code §1311.06(B)). Lien duration/enforcement: lien continues for 6 years from filing unless enforced/otherwise discharged (Ohio Rev. Code §1311.13). Tenant improvements: liens generally attach only if owner is deemed to have consented/authorized; treat as owner_consent_required in this sheet (see generally §1311.04).

Pre-lien notice: for claimants not in privity with owner (e.g., subs/suppliers), a pre-lien notice must be sent to the owner and original contractor within 75 days after last furnishing (for commercial/most projects) to preserve lien rights (42 O.S. §143.2(B)); residential/owner-occupied has stricter limits (see §143.1 and §143.2). This sheet captures 75-day notice as a prelim proxy. Lien filing deadline: original contractor within 4 months after last furnishing; all other claimants within 90 days after last furnishing (42 O.S. §142). Enforcement: suit must be brought within 1 year after filing the lien statement (42 O.S. §172). Owner-occupied/residential: subs/suppliers often have no lien rights absent direct contract or compliance with specific residential notice statutes; this row flags owner_occupied_restriction_type=direct_contract_only as a conservative rule and explains nuance in notes.

Lien filing deadline: generally 75 days after completion of construction for residential construction (ORS 87.035(1)); 90 days after completion for nonresidential/commercial (ORS 87.035(1)). Completion is defined in ORS 87.005 and includes cessation/acceptance. Owner-occupied residential: most claimants not in direct contract must provide an 'Information Notice to Owner' within 8 days after starting work or delivering materials; certain professional services have 5-day timing (ORS 87.039). This sheet encodes 8 days as a general prelim proxy and flags enhanced_notice. Enforcement: suit must be commenced within 2 years after the lien is filed (ORS 87.055). Tenant improvements: lien generally attaches only if owner is an 'owner' under ORS 87.005 or has consent/agency; treat as owner_consent_required.

Lien filing: claim must be filed within 6 months after completion of the claimant’s work (49 P.S. §1502(a)(1)). Serve notice of filing of claim on owner within 1 month after filing (49 P.S. §1502(a)(2)). Enforcement: proceed by writ of scire facias within 2 years after filing claim (49 P.S. §1701). Owner-occupied residential exception: no lien by subcontractor against owner-occupied residential property (generally single family) unless subcontractor has a direct contract with the owner (49 P.S. §1303). PA also recognizes 'Notice of Commencement' concept for certain projects and allows contractual lien waivers in many contexts; not modeled here.

RI is a court-driven lien: claimant must file a 'Notice of Intention' in the Superior Court within 200 days after the last day of furnishing labor/materials (R.I. Gen. Laws §34-28-4). A copy of the Notice of Intention is recorded in the land evidence records of the city/town where the property is located (see §34-28-10). There is a strict petition/hearing process and the lien is contingent on the court’s order; enforcement timelines depend on the court order and subsequent proceedings (see §34-28-16 et seq.). This sheet encodes the 200-day Notice of Intention deadline as the 'lien' deadline and leaves enforcement timing as a placeholder (0) with this note.

Lien filing deadline: statement of mechanic’s lien must be filed within 90 days after the person last furnished labor or materials (S.C. Code Ann. §29-5-90(A)). Service: claimant must serve a copy of the statement of lien on the owner after filing (S.C. Code Ann. §29-5-90(A)); statute does not give a fixed day-count. Enforcement: action to foreclose the lien must be commenced within 6 months after the lien is filed (S.C. Code Ann. §29-5-120). Tenant improvements: lien typically requires owner consent/agency for leasehold work; treated here as owner_consent_required.

Lien filing deadline: file statement of lien within 120 days after last furnishing labor or materials (SDCL §44-9-15). Statement must be verified by oath and filed with the register of deeds (SDCL §44-9-16). Foreclosure/enforcement: SD mechanic’s lien enforcement is tied to bringing an action; a common limitation is 6 years (general actions on record/obligation limitations), so this sheet encodes 72 months as a placeholder; confirm exact foreclosure limitation and any shorter lien-duration rules in SDCL §44-9-23 and related sections.

Recordation: sworn statement/notice of lien must be recorded within 90 days after improvement is complete or abandoned (T.C.A. §66-11-112). Remote contractor prerequisite: serve Notice of Nonpayment on owner and prime contractor within 90 days of the last day of EACH month in which unpaid labor/materials/services/equipment/machinery were furnished (T.C.A. §66-11-145). Remote contractor notice of lien: must be served on owner and recorded within the §66-11-112 time period; lien continues 90 days from date of service and must be enforced by suit within that period (T.C.A. §66-11-115(b) & §66-11-126). Notice of Completion: owner may record after completion; remote contractors with Notice of Nonpayment must be served, and deadlines to preserve/priority can shorten (e.g., 10 days residential / 30 days nonres to respond/file—see T.C.A. §66-11-143(e)). Owner/prime may demand enforcement: suit must be commenced within 60 days after service of demand or lien is forfeited (T.C.A. §66-11-130). Prime contractor enforcement is generally within 1 year after completion/abandonment (see practice summaries; confirm §66-11-106 if you want this coded per claimant).

Lien affidavit deadline for original contractor: residential construction—15th day of 3rd month after month of completion/termination/abandonment; nonresidential—15th day of 4th month (Tex. Prop. Code §53.052(a)(2)). Specially fabricated materials can use later-of logic for filing deadline (see §53.052(b)-(c) and §53.058), modeled here as lien_anchor_logic=later_of with alt field special_fab_delivery_date. Monthly notice regime for derivative claimants is required to preserve lien rights/fund trapping and depends on project type/tier; generally notices are due by the 15th day of the 2nd/3rd month after each month of unpaid labor/materials (Tex. Prop. Code §53.056; see Texas A&M Real Estate Research Center summaries). Notice of filed affidavit: send copy to owner within 5 days after filing; if not original contractor, also send to original contractor within same period (Tex. Prop. Code §53.055). Foreclosure suit deadline: generally 1 year after the last day the claimant may file the lien affidavit under §53.052 (Tex. Prop. Code §53.158); may be extended by written agreement under §53.158(a-2). Texas uses monthly notices (typically due by the 15th day of the 2nd month (res) or 3rd month (com) after each month of unpaid work); this sheet uses 0 + notes to indicate multiple deadlines.

penalty_details: Utah Code 38-9a-201 et seq.: wrongful lien remedies include expedited release + costs/attorney fees; criminal penalties may apply for intentional filing
notes: Preliminary notice: to retain lien rights, a preconstruction/preliminary notice must be filed in the State Construction Registry (SCR) within 20 days after first furnishing labor/service/material/equipment (Utah Code §38-1a-501(1)). Lien recording deadline: lien must be filed within 180 days after final completion of original contract, OR within 90 days after a Notice of Completion is filed in SCR, whichever occurs first (Utah Code §38-1a-502(1)). If preliminary notice not filed, lien rights can be lost (Utah Code §38-1a-501(2)-(3)). Enforcement: action to enforce must be commenced within 180 days after lien recorded (Utah Code §38-1a-701(1)).

Record memorandum of lien within 120 days from the time payment became due; memorandum must be sworn and recorded in the town clerk’s office (9 V.S.A. §1921). Serve copy on owner within 5 days after recording (9 V.S.A. §1921(d)). Enforcement/perfection: within 3 months after recording memorandum, commence action and obtain an order of attachment of the real estate and record a certified copy of the attachment order in the town clerk’s office (9 V.S.A. §1923).

Lien filing (memorandum): record in circuit court clerk’s office. Deadline is the later of (i) 90 days from the last day of the month of last furnishing, or (ii) 90 days from completion/termination of the building/contract; BUT never later than 150 days from last furnishing (Va. Code §43-4). This sheet models later_of using lien_anchor_logic=later_of with alt=contract_terminated_date; enforce the 150-day cap in app logic. Service: memorandum must be served on the owner or owner’s agent (Va. Code §§43-4, 43-5). Enforcement: suit must be brought within 6 months after memorandum recorded OR within 60 days after completion/termination, whichever is later (Va. Code §43-17).

penalty_details: RCW 60.04.081/171: frivolous lien motion; court may award costs and reasonable attorney fees; damages possible
notes: Residential notice: for owner-occupied single-family residences, certain lien claimants (notably material suppliers) must provide the statutory pre-claim notice (RCW 60.04.031). This sheet encodes a 10-day after first furnishing proxy; statute timing is tied to first delivery/provision and form content. Lien filing: record claim of lien within 90 days after last furnishing labor/materials/equipment (RCW 60.04.091). Serve copy of recorded claim of lien on the owner within 14 days after filing (RCW 60.04.091). Enforcement: commence action to foreclose within 8 months after claim filed (RCW 60.04.141). Frivolous lien remedies: motion to release + attorney fees (RCW 60.04.171).

Lien filing deadline: file a verified lien within 100 days after the claimant ceased to furnish labor or materials (W. Va. Code §38-2-7). Enforcement: action to enforce a mechanic’s lien must be brought within 6 months after filing the lien (W. Va. Code §38-2-34). Tenant improvements typically require owner consent/agency to reach fee interest; treated here as owner_consent_required.

penalty_details: Wis. Stat. §779.12: claimant who files exaggerated/fraudulent lien may be liable for damages; lien may be voided
notes: Owner-occupied 1–4 family residential: subs/suppliers must give 'Notice of Right to Lien' within 60 days after first furnishing; late notice limits lien to unpaid amounts owed after notice is received (Wis. Stat. §779.02(2)(b)). Lien filing deadline: file claim for lien within 6 months after last furnishing labor/materials (Wis. Stat. §779.06(1)). Enforcement: action to enforce/foreclose must be commenced within 2 years after filing the claim for lien (Wis. Stat. §779.06(2)). Lien waivers and owner protections exist; tenant improvements generally require owner consent/agency to reach fee interest.

Lien filing deadlines: original contractor must file lien statement within 150 days after completion of the contract; subcontractors/material suppliers generally within 120 days after last furnishing (see Wyo. Stat. §§29-2-106 & 29-2-107). Enforcement: action to enforce lien must be commenced within 180 days after filing the lien statement (Wyo. Stat. §29-2-109).
